questions.text: Identify the following poisonous snake.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Explanation of other options:

Russell's viper (Option A): Hemotoxic bite; identified by 3 rows of diamond-shaped spots and triangular head.

Saw-scaled viper (Option B): Hemotoxic; has serrated scales that produce a rasping sound.

King cobra (Option C): Neurotoxic, but has a hood and lacks the narrow white banding.

Key Takeaway:
Common krait is a neurotoxic elapid snake, identified by glossy black skin with narrow white bands and minimal local signs post-bite.

questions.text: Snake that causes paralysis with convulsions:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Convulsions are more common in common cobra along with muscular paralysis.
  • Krait causes only paralysis. Local signs are almost nil.
  • Vipers cause bleeding from external orifices with maximum local signs.
  • Sea snakes produce muscle paralysis and muscle necrosis.

Explanation of other options:

Vipers (Option A): Hemotoxic venom; no convulsions; marked local swelling and coagulopathy.

Sea snakes (Option B): Cause muscle necrosis and flaccid paralysis.

Krait (Option D): Causes pure neuroparalysis without convulsions and minimal local symptoms.

Key Takeaway:
Cobra bites are unique among neurotoxic snakes for causing convulsions with muscular paralysis, often with prominent local tissue effects.

questions.text: Neurotoxic snake is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Krait venom is neurotoxic, affecting neuromuscular transmission and leading to respiratory paralysis.

  • Neurotoxic snakes cause paralysis by acting at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Krait (Bungarus caeruleus) venom contains presynaptic neurotoxins (β-bungarotoxin) and postsynaptic toxins that block acetylcholine release and receptor binding.
  • This leads to progressive muscular paralysis, ptosis, and eventually respiratory failure.
  • Cobra venom is also neurotoxic, but kraits typically cause paralysis without significant local symptoms.

Key Takeaway:

Krait is a neurotoxic snake causing paralysis without local signs due to its potent presynaptic neurotoxins.

questions.text: A 25-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department 3 hours after a snakebite on his right leg. On examination, there is severe local swelling, oozing from the puncture site, and ecchymosis extending up the limb. He also has bleeding from gums and hematuria. Laboratory investigations reveal prolonged clotting time and elevated serum creatinine. Which of the following is the most likely snake species responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Viper venom is vasculotoxic, causing bleeding disorders and coagulopathy by damaging endothelial cells and lysing red cells.

  • Viper venom is vasculotoxic, acting on vascular endothelium leading to:
    • Hemorrhage
    • Coagulation defects
    • Hemolysis
  • Common effects include:
    • Bleeding from external orifices
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Swelling, ecchymosis, and cellulitis at the bite site
  • Viper bites may lead to renal failure due to hemoglobinuria and hypotension.

Explanation of other options:

Common cobra (Option A): Causes neurotoxic paralysis with minimal local or hematological involvement.

Common krait (Option B): Purely neurotoxic, causing respiratory paralysis without local or hematological signs.

Sea snake (Option D): Primarily myotoxic, resulting in rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria—not hematological issues.

Key Takeaway:
Vipers are hematotoxic and cause bleeding, coagulation abnormalities, and local tissue destruction.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of snakebite 4 hours ago along with ptosis, paralysis and external ophthalmoplegia. On examination bite mark cannot be visualized and there is no swelling of the limb. Most probable species implicated is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Common krait bites are painless, often without visible fang marks or swelling, yet cause severe neuroparalytic features.

Common krait venom is neurotoxic, affecting the motor end plates.

Characteristic features:

  • No local inflammation
  • Fang marks not visible due to short fangs
  • Painless bite, usually at night
  • Neurological features: ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, limb weakness, respiratory paralysis

Differentiating factor: Cobra also causes neurotoxicity but produces visible local signs.

Vipers cause bleeding and local swelling due to vasculotoxic venom.

Sea snakes cause myotoxicity, typically resulting in muscle necrosis and myoglobinuria. 

Key Takeaway:

Painless bite, absence of fang marks and local swelling, and pure neuroparalysis point strongly toward common krait envenomation.

questions.text: Treatment of snakebite are all, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary management (First aid) in a case of snake bite:

  • Best is immobilization → By application of splint
  • Assurance/Reassurance
  • Do not wash the area of the bite.
  • No tourniquet application.
  • Sutherland wrapping: Pressure application by crepe bandage if the victim is expected to reach the hospital in more than 30 minutes but less than 3 hours. The bandage is wrapped over the bitten area as well as the entire limb with the limb placed in a splint.  It should be capable of admitting a finger beneath it.
  • Keep the affected area below heart level to reduce the flow of venom.
  • No incision & suction.
  • No ice application.
  • No electrotherapy.

Hospital treatment  

  • Wait and watch for signs & symptoms.
  • If indicated → Begin PASV (Polyvalent anti snake venom) with 10 vials.
  • PASV is effective against 1. Common cobra, 2. Common krait, 3. Russel’s viper, and 4. Saw scaled viper
  • PASV produced by Hoffkine biopharmaceutical company neutralises venom of pit viper due to para-specific activity.

Fixation of toxins

  • Common cobra → neurotoxins get fixed at post synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has a role.
  • Common krait → neurotoxins get fixed at pre-synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has no role.

Key Takeaway:
Incision and suction are outdated and harmful; modern first aid for snakebite emphasizes immobilisation, pressure bandage, and reassurance.

Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/stg/Snakebite_QRG.pdf http://repository-tnmgrmu.ac.in/18612/1/14110400021mohanraj.pdf

questions.text: In a confirmed case of snake envenomation, what is the recommended initial dose of Polyvalent Anti-Snake Venom (PASV)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended initial dose of PASV is 8–10 vials IV, administered slowly over one hour in moderate to severe envenomation.

  • Repeat doses for vasculotoxic species is based on the 6 hours rule (depending on the coagulation profile); the maximum recommended dose is 30 vials.
  • Repeat doses for neurotoxicity is based on the 1-2 hours rule (depending on whether patients have not improved, or worsened); maximum dose is 20 vials.
  • Antivenin treatment should be given, as soon as it is indicated. Ideally PASV should be administered within 4 hours, but effective even if it is given within 24 hours.

Key Takeaway:
The initial PASV dose in snakebite is 8–10 vials IV, tailored by type and severity of envenomation.

questions.text:
True about snake bite and ASV
1.Lower dose in infant as compared to adults
2.Sensitivity test must be done before ASV
3.Useful for venom associated coagulopathy in viper bites
4.Cobra venom acts at presynaptic region
5.Common krait venom causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ASV is useful for venom associated coagulopathy in viper bites; as the viper venom is hemotoxic in nature. Common krait venom is neurotoxic which causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia manifesting with ptosis.

Children and pregnant women receive the same ASV dosage as adults. The ASV is targeted at neutralizing the venom. Snakes inject the same amount of venom into adults and children.

No ASV test dose must be administered: Test doses have been shown to have no predictive value in detecting anaphylactic or late serum reactions and should not be used. These reactions are not IgE mediated but Complement activated, They may also pre-sensitize the patient and thereby create greater risk.

Common cobra → neurotoxins get fixed at post synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has a role.

Key Takeaway:
ASV neutralizes venom-related coagulopathy (viper), and krait causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia; no test dose is required.

Reference:
API Medicine Update 2017, Chapter on Snake Bite Management: https://apiindia.org/uploads/pdf/medicine_update_2017/mu_113.pdf

questions.text: A 3-year-old child sleeping in a hut woke up in the middle of the night screaming. Her mother thought the child had a nightmare and tried to pacify her. After some time, the child started sweating profusely and the hands became cold. She vomited a couple of times. The mother immediately rushed her to the emergency services. Her pulse was 150/minute and her BP 90/60 mm Hg. This child is likely to have:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history and signs & symptoms are suggestive of scorpion sting.

Action of Scorpion venom:

Scorpion venom is neurotoxic, hemotoxic and cardiotoxic, but predominantly neurotoxic. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator, resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It has also some direct effect on the myocardium.

Signs and Symptoms of scorpion sting:

In case of haemolytic venom, reaction is mainly local and simulates viperine bite, but the scorpion sting bite shows only one hole in the centre of the reddened area at the site of bite.

Neurotoxic bite simulates cobra bite.

Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours.

Local:

Little swelling, but prominent radiating pain, reddening, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (tap test).

Systemic effects

Nausea, vomiting, restlessness, fever, headache, giddiness, sweating, muscular fasciculations, jerking and shaking (may be mistaken for a seizure), slow pulse, cyanosis, convulsions, coma and respiratory depression, and death may occur from pulmonary edema or cardiac failure in children.

Complications:

Tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, and acidosis.

Explanation of other options:

Snakebite (Option A): No visible fang marks or neuroparalytic features; no swelling suggests it’s less likely.

Septic shock (Option C): Would progress over hours/days, not sudden onset during sleep.

Food poisoning (Option D): May cause vomiting, but autonomic storm (sweating, cold extremities, tachycardia) is not a typical presentation.

Key Takeaway:
In a child from a rural setup with sudden autonomic symptoms at night, scorpion sting should be the first differential.

questions.text: Active ingredient of marking nut is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marking nuts (bhilwa) are black, heart-shaped with rough projection at the base. They have a thick, cellular pericarp, which contains an irritant juice which is brownish, oily and acrid but turns black on exposure to air. The active principles are semecarpol (0.1%) and bhilawanol (15 to 17% ).

Signs and Symptoms:

  • When the juice from seeds of semicarpus anacardium (marking nut) is applied to the skin, it causes irritation, itching redness, burning sensation, and a painful blister containing acrid serum and eczematous contact dermatitis.
  • The lesion resembles a bruise. The rash takes 1-2 weeks to heal and normally does not leave scars.
  • Severe cases have small (1-2 mm) clear fluid-filled blisters on the skin. Sometimes, an ulcer may be produced with sloughing. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, painful micturition with brown colour urine may be seen.

Explanation of other options:

Croton (Option B): Source of croton oil, a different strong irritant but not found in marking nut.

Abrin (Option C): Found in Abrus precatorius (rosary pea), a toxalbumin—not a skin irritant.

Ricin (Option D): Potent toxalbumin from Ricinus communis (castor), highly toxic but unrelated to skin irritation.

Key Takeaway:
Semecarpol is the primary irritant in marking nut, used in malingering to simulate bruises.

questions.text: Juice of Semecarpus anacardium can be used for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medicolegal aspects of semecarpus anacardium:

  • Accidental poisoning may result from the administration of juice by quacks for treatment of rheumatic pain and worm infestation.
  • Cases of contact dermatitis (due to urushiol) related to its use as hair dye, voodoo treatment, remedy for eczema or tattoo removal have been reported.
  • Anaphylaxis due unintentional oral ingestion related to marking nut has also been reported.
  • Juice may be introduced into the vagina, as a punishment for infidelity.
  • For criminal abortion, juice is applied to the cervical os by means of abortion stick.
  • It may be used by malingerers to produce ;conjunctivitis or to support a false charge of assault; lesions produced simulate bruises.
  • The juice may be thrown on the face to cause injury (vitriolage).

Key Takeaway:
The irritant juice of Semecarpus anacardium may be used to simulate vitriolage by mimicking chemical burn injuries.

questions.text: Hunan hand occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

'Hunan hand' ('Chilli Willy') is a painful contact dermatitis seen in people with continuous and prolonged exposure to chilli peppers containing capsaicin.

  • This is paradoxical to the use of capsaicin as local application for relief of pain in various conditions like diabetic neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia.

Explanation of other options:

Abrus precatorius (Option A): Contains abrin, a toxalbumin causing systemic toxicity.

Datura (Option C): Causes anticholinergic syndrome—delirium, mydriasis.

Strychnine (Option D): Leads to convulsions due to inhibition of spinal glycine receptors.

Key Takeaway:
Chronic handling of chili peppers rich in capsaicin causes Hunan hand, a painful irritant dermatitis.

questions.text: St. Anthony's fire characterized by burning pain is due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ergot is the dried sclerotium of the fungus Claviceps purpurea which grows on stale grains, particularly rye, barley, maize and wheat.

Fatal dose: 1-2 g.

Fatal period: Few days.

Chronic poisoning (ergotism) may either be convulsive or gangrenous in type.

  • In convulsive type, there is twitching, tingling, numbness and pain in the muscles. There may be headache, drowsiness, giddiness, formication and convulsions.
  • In gangrenous type, which resembles Raynaud's disease, there is a burning pain (called St. Anthony's fire)in the limbs with alternating heat and cold sense, numbness and tingling or anaesthesia. "In fingers, toes, ears, nose, hands and feet, there may be dry gangrene without swelling and ulceration.

Explanation of other options:

Cocaine (Option A): Causes vasoconstriction but typically leads to nasal septum perforation or myocardial ischemia.

Abrus precatorius (Option B): Contains abrin, a toxalbumin—causes GI and systemic symptoms, not burning pain with gangrene.

Clostridium botulinum (Option D): Produces flaccid paralysis due to inhibition of acetylcholine release.

Key Takeaway:
Burning pain in limbs with dry gangrene following stale grain ingestion is classical of ergotism caused by Claviceps purpurea.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of accidental ingestion of a white powder used as rodenticide. Within 30 minutes, he develops painful generalized convulsions, opisthotonus, and is conscious between episodes. On examination, stimuli such as light and sound trigger convulsions. What is the most likely neurotransmitter blocked by the ingested toxin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Strychnine competitively blocks ventral horn motor neurone postganglionic receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem and prevents the effects of glycine (the presumed inhibitory transmitter).
  • Widespread inhibition in the spinal cord results in 'release' excitation.
  • The action is particularly noted in the anterior horn cells.
  • It stimulates the cerebral cortex.
  • GABA, the neurotransmitter for presynaptic inhibitory neurons is not affected.

Key Takeaway:
Strychnine poisoning causes painful reflex convulsions by blocking glycine, the key inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord.

choices.text: Becomes unconscious in 1 hour or so

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with painful convulsions, opisthotonus, and intermittent arching of the back triggered by sudden sounds or touch. His attendants report he had ingested a traditional herbal preparation made from crushed seeds about 2 hours ago. Which of the following statements best describes the neurological status in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Strychnos nux vomica contains strychnine. It is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postsynaptic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons.

The toxin strychnine does not affect any receptors in the brain and the person remains conscious till death. Strychnine poisoning is characterized by conscious seizures.

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature called postmortem caloricity.

Key Takeaway: 

Strychnine causes painful reflex convulsions without loss of consciousness, as it spares higher cortical centers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male farm worker is brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe, painful spasms that began shortly after ingesting an unknown crushed seed preparation as a traditional remedy. He is conscious, alert, but extremely anxious and responds to touch or noise with intense, generalized tonic spasms. On examination, his back is hyperextended, and only his head and heels touch the bed, with the trunk lifted in a classic arching posture. There is no trismus or autonomic instability. Which of the following best describes this posture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Opisthotonus is the hallmark extensor posture seen in strychnine poisoning due to glycine inhibition at anterior horn cells.

  • The clinical clues-conscious seizures, exaggerated response to sensory stimuli, and arched posture—strongly suggest strychnine poisoning.
  • Strychnine antagonizes glycine receptors at spinal cord anterior horn cells, disinhibiting motor neurons.
  • This causes simultaneous contraction of extensor muscles, producing the opisthotonus posture.
  • Unlike tetanus, no trismus or autonomic symptoms are noted here.

Explanation of other options:

Emprosthotonus (Option A): Forward flexion seen occasionally in tetanus or rare poisonings.

Pleurosthotonus (Option B): Lateral trunk bending posture, rarely dominant in any toxidrome.

Decerebrate rigidity (Option D): Extensor posturing from brainstem injury-associated with unconsciousness, not conscious seizures.

Key Takeaway:
Opisthotonus with preserved consciousness following seed ingestion points to strychnine (nux vomica) poisoning.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe painful spasms triggered by even mild noise or touch. He remains fully conscious during repeated tonic convulsions and shows opisthotonus. His friends admit he consumed a traditional remedy containing unknown seeds. What is the most appropriate pharmacologic agent for controlling his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Treatment for strychnine poisoning involves supportive care with minimization of external stimulus and prevention of convulsions.

  1. Maintain clear airway and adequate ventilation including endotracheal intubation.
  2. Control of convulsions: Dark room, free from noise and disturbance. Diazepam 0.1-0.5 mg/kg IV slowly. If ineffective, general anesthetics and/or muscle relaxants, like gallamine should be given.
  3. Barbiturates, like pentobarbital sodium or sodium amytal are antidotes.
  4. Gastric lavage with KMnO4, may be done cautiously after securing the airway with an endotracheal tube, if there are no convulsions.
  5. Hyperthermia is treated by active cooling with ice water immersion, cooling blanket or mist and fan.
  6. Intravenous fluid is given to maintain a urine output >1 ml/kg/h, since metabolic acidosis and renal failure may occur.
  7. Hemodialysis is not effective as strychnine is rapidly distributed to the tissues.
  8. Symptomatic treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Fomepizole (Option A): Used in methanol/ethylene glycol poisoning.

Physostigmine (Option B): Used in anticholinergic toxicity.

Naloxone (Option D): Opioid antagonist.

Key Takeaway:
Barbiturates are effective in managing strychnine-induced conscious seizures by CNS depression and muscle relaxation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man collapses after consuming a self-prepared herbal decoction. He is found to have bradycardia, hypotension, and life-threatening arrhythmias. On ECG, there is QT prolongation and frequent ventricular ectopics. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause of cardiotoxicity in such poisonings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Opium is a CNS depressant and respiratory suppressant, but not primarily cardiotoxic, unlike the other listed agents.

  • Aconite, Oleander, Nicotine are all well-known cardiac poisons causing bradycardia, arrhythmias, and even cardiac arrest.
  • Opium, derived from Papaver somniferum, mainly affects the central nervous system, leading to:
    • Miosis
    • Respiratory depression
    • Coma
  • It does not cause direct myocardial toxicity or conduction defects characteristic of the other poisons listed.

Key Takeaway:
Opium is not cardiotoxic—its toxic effects are CNS and respiratory in nature.

questions.text: Mitha bish is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ACONITE

All parts of the plant are poisonous; however, the root and root tubers are the most potent.

Roots are mistaken for horseradish root.

Synonyms: Monk's hood, mitha zaher, mitha  bish, wolf's bane, women's bane, devil's helmet or blue rocket

  • Toxic symptoms include:
    • Tingling and numbness of lips and tongue
    • Hypotension, bradycardia or tachyarrhythmia
    • Ventricular fibrillation and sudden death
  • Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels → prolonged depolarization

Key Takeaway:
 “Mitha Bish” refers to Aconite, a root-based plant poison that acts rapidly and is fatal if ingested.

questions.text: Not a sign/symptom of aconite poisoning
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aconite poisoning typically causes hypotension, not hypertension, due to myocardial depression and arrhythmias.

Key Takeaway:
Aconite poisoning causes hypotension, bradycardia, paresthesias, GI upset, and visual disturbances—but not hypertension.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with bradycardia, vomiting, and hyperkalemia after suspected ingestion of crushed leaves from a garden shrub known for its ornamental flowers. Which of the following is the most likely active principle involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nerin is the cardiac glycoside active principle found in pink or white oleander (Nerium odorum), responsible for its cardiotoxic effects.

  • Nerium odorum (pink/white oleander) contains glycosides like Nerin, Folinerin, and Rosagenin.
  • These glycosides act similar to digitalis: they inhibit Na+/K+-ATPase, leading to increased intracellular calcium and resulting in arrhythmias.
  • Oleander poisoning is a common cause of plant-induced cardiac toxicity in India.
  • Clinical features include nausea, vomiting, bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and ventricular arrhythmias.


Explanation of other options:

Cannabinol (Option A): Derived from cannabis; causes CNS depression and hallucinations, not cardiotoxicity.

Atropine (Option B): Found in belladonna; anticholinergic agent causing dry mouth, tachycardia, and delirium.

Semecarpol (Option C): Found in Semecarpus anacardium (marking nut); causes dermatitis, not cardiac effects.

Key Takeaway:

Nerin is the primary cardiac glycoside in Nerium odorum (oleander), responsible for life-threatening arrhythmias.
